Award.AwardTitle: Adaptive designs: Sequential tests of multiple hypotheses
Award.AbstractNarration:
The investigator will develop adaptive designs for the analysis of multiple sequential data streams, about which it is desired to test a set of statistical hypotheses. The designs will require minimal knowledge (none in some cases) of the dependence between these data streams -- since such dependence is often strong but difficult or impossible to model in practice -- and will provide sequential multiple hypothesis testing procedures which reach conclusions about each individual stream and hypothesis individually, as well as the set of hypotheses as a whole by controlling overall error rates, while being adaptively efficient by "dropping" a data stream once no additional information is needed to reach a confident conclusion. This will be done for the two most widely-used multiple testing error metrics, false-discovery rate and familywise error rate. For these two metrics, the investigator will: (1) develop sequential multiple testing procedures and a unified theory for existing procedures; (2) assess their performance and optimality through analysis and extensive numerical simulations; (3) find expressions or approximations for their operating characteristics including achieved error rates and expected total and maximum sample size; (4) apply the procedures to real data in genetics, genomics, and multi-arm biomedical trials and modify the procedures to aid practical implementation in these areas; and (5) develop free software packages to facilitate applications.

The project will provide new statistical methods to handle the analysis of multiple data streams arriving sequentially over time in a coherent fashion. The need to handle this type of data arises in a plethora of real-world situations including terrorist threat detection, quality control, finance, biomedical clinical trials for new treatments, disease monitoring in human and animal populations, genetics, and genomics. Despite this, there are few existing statistical procedures that one can use except in some special cases. The procedures developed in this project will therefore be widely applicable by scientists and workers in these areas. Methodologically, the work will be a breakthrough in a fundamental yet largely unexplored area of statistics, with many benefits and broader impacts to society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcomes of this work are new statistical procedures to address data in situations that could not be handled before: many streams of data that must be analyzed in real time and inference made on each in a statistically valid way. These methods have been developed, studied theoretically, and implemented to study data from a drug side effect reporting database, among other real world applications.  In this setting the procedures allow earlier detection of drugs and treatments that have harmful side effects.

More specifically the following was carried out.
1. Step down sequential multiple testing procedures were found that provably control FDR without any specialized knowledge or modeling of the dependence structure by the statistician, which is often difficult or impossible in practice.

2. Critical values for the FDR-controlling procedures were found for commonly-encountered testing situations. Closed-form expressions were found for simple vs. simple hypotheses and for one-sided hypotheses in monotone likelihood ratio families.  For other composite hypotheses, it was shown that signed-root normal approximations can be used for certain commonly-encountered hypotheses in the multiparameter exponential family (e.g., testing with nuisance parameters).  In still other situations, it was shown that Monte Carlo can be used, and how to avoid the curse of dimensionality in many cases.

3.  The resulting procedures were applied to big, streaming data from the YellowCard pharmocovigilence spontaneous reporting system. Applying the new procedures, harmful treatments can be detected in real time and flagged for further evaluation.
